definition.p: The following are known as separation axioms for a topological space \tuple{X,\mc T}.

ol.li:
\mc T is said to be T_0 if and only if for all points x,y\in X such that x
ot=y, there either exists a neighborhood U of x such that y
ot\in U, or there exists a neighborhood V of y such that x
ot\in V.
\mc T is said to be T_1 if and only if for all points x,y\in X such that x\not=y, there exists a neighborhood U of x such that y\not\in U.
\mc T is said to be T_2 (also known as Hausdorff) if and only if for all points x,y\in X such that x\not=y, there exist neighborhoods U,V of x,y (respectively) such that U\cap V=\emptyset.

theorem.p: A topological space X is T_1 if and only if every finite subset of X is closed.

corollary.p: Let X be a finite topological space. Then X is T_1 if and only if X has the discrete topology.

proposition.p: The Euclidean real line is an example of a Hausdorff topological space that does not have the discrete topology.

definition.p: The following are also known as separation axioms for a topological space \tuple{X,\mc T}.

ol.li: \mc T is said to be regular if and only if for all points x\in X and closed subsets H\subseteq X such that x\not\in H, there exist open sets U,V\in\mc T such that x\in U,H\subseteq V,U\cap V=\emptyset.
\mc T is said to be T_3 if and only if it is both regular and T_1
\mc T is said to be normal if and only if for all closed subsets H,L\subseteq X such that H\cap L=\emptyset, there exist open sets U,V\in\mc T such that H\subseteq U,L\subseteq V,U\cap V=\emptyset.
\mc T is said to be T_4 if and only if it is both normal and T_1

theorem.p: The real line \mb R equipped with the Euclidean topology is T_4.

proposition.p: A space is regular if and only if for every point x and neighborhood U, there exists a neighborhood V of x such that x\in V\subseteq\cl V\subseteq U.
A space is normal if and only if for closed set H and open set U\supseteq H, there exists an open set V\supseteq H such that H\subseteq V\subseteq\cl V\subseteq U.

theorem.p: A topological space is T_3 if and only if it is regular and T_0.

proposition.p: Let n\in\setList{0,1,2,3}. A subspace of a T_n space is also T_n.
Let n\in\setList{0,1,2} and f:X\to Y be continuous. If Y is T_n, then X is also T_n.

theorem.p: Let n\in\setList{3,4} and f:X\to Y be a continuous closed map. If Y is T_n, then X is also T_n.

corollary.p: Separation properties are topological properties (that is, preserved by homeomorphism).
